title: 106_hr4199
content: The "Date Certain Tax Code Replacement Act" sets a specific date for replacing the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 with a simpler and fairer alternative. The "Date Certain Tax Code Replacement Act" specifies the termination of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 after December 31, 2004, with exceptions for specific taxes. Additionally, it establishes a National Commission on Tax Reform and Simplification. The Congress acknowledges that the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is overly complex, burdensome for individuals and businesses, and in need of fundamental reform and simplification. The current fiscal surplus provides a unique opportunity for tax law reform, as previous efforts have not been successful. The Internal Revenue Service faces challenges due to the complex tax code it administers. A National Commission on Tax Reform and Simplification is established within the legislative branch to address these issues with 15 members appointed by the President and the majority leader. The National Commission on Tax Reform and Simplification is established within the legislative branch with 12 members appointed by the majority and minority leaders of the Senate and the Speaker and minority leader of the House of Representatives. The Commission will elect a Chair from among its members and meet as needed. The Commission shall meet upon the call of the Chair or a majority of its members, with nine members constituting a quorum. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Meetings may be held in executive session if deemed appropriate. If a member appointing individual ceases their position before the report submission, or if a member leaves before the report submission, their membership will continue. The Commission members should be appointed within 60 days of the enactment of the Act. If a member appointed from Congress or not a government officer later becomes one, they can continue for up to 30 days after leaving their position. The Commission must be appointed within 60 days of the Act's enactment. After 60 days, if eight or more members are appointed, they can select a Chair to start operations, including hiring staff. The Commission's functions include conducting a review for up to 18 months and submitting a report to Congress with recommendations. The Commission will conduct a review of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, focusing on its impact on the economy, families, compliance costs, and taxpayer burden. Recommendations for fundamental reform and simplification will be included in the report to Congress. The Commission will review the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, considering the IRS's ability to administer it, exploring more efficient tax systems from other countries, evaluating the possibility of replacing income tax with a different tax, and simplifying the code without complete restructuring. The Commission has the power to authorize subcommittees or members to carry out its provisions. The Commission, in carrying out its provisions, may hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and enter into contracts as needed. It is authorized to secure information from various federal agencies and offices. The Commission can request information, suggestions, estimates, and statistics from federal departments, agencies, and committees for its review. The Treasury Department can provide administrative services and support to the Commission. The Commission can request administrative support services, legal analysis, and other assistance from various federal departments, agencies, and committees. The General Services Administration and Joint Committee on Taxation are among the entities authorized to provide nonreimbursable support to the Commission. The Commission is authorized to receive support services, funds, facilities, staff, and other assistance from US departments and agencies. It can also use postal services, accept gifts, and appoint a staff director as needed. The Commission can appoint a staff director and necessary personnel without following certain regulations, with a pay limit set at level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, retaining their rights and privileges. The Commission can appoint staff and consultants at rates not exceeding level IV of the Executive Schedule. Members may be compensated at a daily rate equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule. Members of the Commission are compensated at a daily rate equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule. They are also allowed travel expenses while performing services for the Commission. Officers or employees of the United States or Members of Congress serving on the Commission do not receive additional pay. The Commission must submit a report to the House Ways and Means Committee and Senate Finance Committee within 18 months of its first meeting. The report will detail the results of its review, recommend reforms to the tax code, and assess the impact of these recommendations. The Commission will terminate once its duties are fulfilled. The Commission's activities will end 90 days after the report is due, with a 90-day period for concluding activities. Authorization of appropriations is granted for the Commission's work, with $2,000,000 available from fiscal year 2001 funds until specific appropriations are made. SEC. 5. TIMING OF IMPLEMENTATION. Congress declares that any new Federal tax system must be approved in its final form by July 4, 2004. If not approved by then, Congress must vote to reauthorize the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
